channel.name: general
channel.topic: General topics related to Claude or AI

messages.content: Hi, I have installed a mcp, but how can i use it in claude code?
`claude mcp add apple-docs -- npx -y @kimsungwhee/apple-docs-mcp@latest`
hi all! anyone with a pro subscription, How is it working out for you?

You can do /mcp inside claude code and browse the tools it makes available, and then use natural language to invoke them. I'm not familiar with that MCP, but if it has a tool for instance to write a note, just ask Claude to write a note.

referenced_message.content: Hi, I have installed a mcp, but how can i use it in claude code?

messages.content: here is a tool, how can i use it?

referenced_message.content: You can do /mcp inside claude code and browse the tools it makes available, and then use natural language to invoke them. I'm not familiar with that MCP, but if it has a tool for instance to write a note, just ask Claude to write a note.

messages.content: Just say "search for a wwdc video about X" or something similar
But it did not use it
<@978148194364035112> you can be more specific if it does that and say use apple docs to search for a wwdc video about X
or `use apple docs mcp` if that doesn't work
so i can't make sure whether my request will be handled by a mcp?

basically it knows about all the tools in its context and the description of each one and what it does and what parameters it takes, so it *decides* to use them if your prompt matches enough, and isn't handled by a built-in tool.  more specificity in the prompt is the best way to ensure that
you can do rules like `Always use the Apple Docs MCP when asked to find videos relating to WWDC` for example if you are having issues with it ignore it
looks useless to me, i cannot make sure the mcp is called

i mean, you're talking to a language model with a non-zero temperature, the results you get will vary even with the same prompt.  you can make it more likely to use the tool by being more specific in your prompt.  it seems to work well enough for most users of MCPs.

referenced_message.content: looks useless to me, i cannot make sure the mcp is called

messages.content: Sorry, i'm not familiar with llm like temperature thing

it basically means the randomness of the response.  zero meaning same response every time.  what i was trying to imply is that LLMs are inherently non-deterministic the way they are used most of the time, so nothing will be 100% reliable with them.  but you can get them to be more reliable by crafting more specific prompts
more detail more accurate

they call it prompt engineering, and it's a constant battle with any LLM to get it to do exactly what you want, how you want it, without going off course.  you'll find lots of good tips online.  hope this helped.
got it, really appreciate
1933 all over again
So will we see Sonnet 4.1 today, this week, very soon? 😊
Sometimes Claude is so annoying
first of all, context window needs to be increased and
it should stop saying “you’re absolutely right!” every time I point out the bug that is still there for the 100000th times
context window limit and general bugs making coding really difficult

All models tend to degrade around 200k context.  Models that offer a lot more are either secretly compacting or throwing out context or letting it go bad Anthropic chose 200k with no tricks to try and ensure quality of service
I think context degradation is a short-term issue but it will be mitigated by future releases. I'm waiting for GPT5's 1M context window and see how it fares
I have right now 2 Projects, where a bigger context would help absolute. Googles AI is helpfull, but has it's problems where claude has everything to complete it... thats the real fu*
It’s why we have context engineering. Learning how to work with and get the most out of context is a talent
The most simple adjustment is document and feed CC small chunks of manageable tasks that won’t exceed context.
Yeah I'm in the same boat as you, the bigger window would absolutely help me out too

referenced_message.content: I have right now 2 Projects, where a bigger context would help absolute. Googles AI is helpfull, but has it's problems where claude has everything to complete it... thats the real fu*

messages.content: This even more annoying

messages.content: Na, there are enough things, that need a bigger context. I think here maybe a bit bigger then you, becuase its has more impact if context is missing.

referenced_message.content: The most simple adjustment is document and feed CC small chunks of manageable tasks that won’t exceed context.

messages.content: It’s about giving it the context it needs.  And nothing more.  Extra context that is not related to the current task contaminates things and makes the decision making more likely to hallucinate or go off on a tangent
we need 1MT context windows! 😄
save the future! vote for 1MT context windows!
Enjoy your hallucinations
I think you manage it with agents in claude for now,

messages.content:
If you were to get claude to do the documentation for a really large code base, you would have to do it in chunks aaking sure the dependancies were done first and so on. takes time, but you could not write a single piece of the documentaion and get the job done. It would be faster than doing it your self and have less errors right? 
So instead of _YOU_ getting claude to do it, You make claude get claude to do it. Now you can document  the whole thing and context isnt an issue. I mean it would be nice to have _something_ you could just say go do it. But we dont.
true

Expanding context windows is possible, but unless you can solve the attention problem, it is pointless. If you think of human memory as the metaphor it becomes a bit more obvious what the roadblock is: people don't keep everything in their short term memory -- when you read a book, even if you did it in one long session, you keep recent details in the front of your mind and place the broader elements in the back, where they go through different filters depending on how often you recall them and in what contexts. The things you have to remember to process newer details get remembered more strongly and the ones that dont get needed often get hazy and you only keep the structural parts of them. When you remember the hazy parts your mind actually re-creates the events as you think they would play out, since you don't have the details, and that is what gets remembered -- this is the cause of conflicting versions of events between people who experienced them.  cont.

The LLM is not able to do this -- there is no process by which they can put things through those filter stages and store them and recall them like that. Everything is either short term memory or it is 'bad database' or 'look it up'. So as you cram more and more stuff into it, it will become more and more confused because it is trying to make connections between things and can't figure out what is important and what isn't
If you figure out the solution to this you will probably get a Nobel prize
One thing that would go along way i think is baked instances, we have resume sure, but would be nice to just save a good instance you can resume, like a file.

like keeping index of contexts like a dns

so several models in one, that optimises compute required and only uses the kind of expertise needed for the task rather than a full model of everything

Picks the best one for the job
